A teen-aged girl gets the horse of her dreams and is trained by an ex-Jockey to participate in London's Grand National Steeplechase. In the course of her training, the girl meets a charming aristocrat who offers to fix the race for an entry fee. She is then faced with having to juggle between her hatred for the horse and her friends lives.

A River Runs Through It is based on the true story of two fly fishing brothers, Norman and Paul, (Brad Pitt and Craig Sheffer) whose Reverend father ( Tom Skerritt ) tries to teach them life’s lessons by way of Fly Fishing. This movie is nothing short of a dark, gritty masterpiece. I may be bias, as the Apartheid era is an area I've always felt for South Africans. I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it quite a bit more by the end. "Les Valseuses" is a classic piece of French cinema, and for a good reason. It's quite provocative, daring, and a tad different from the usual fare that Bertrand Blier has found success with.
